author: Chris Leadbeater
title: Alternatives to the Dover-Calais ferry
text: So near and yet so far. Calais may be just 26 miles from Dover, but northern France’s main port seems considerably more distant at the moment – made less accessible by a combination of striking ferry workers and migrants seeking to reach Britain, which has caused the cancellation of cross-Channel services, long delays and tailbacks of lorries on the M20. If you have booked a crossing already, read our expert advice on whether you can cancel or postpone your trip. If you have yet to book, don't despair, there are alternative ways to cross the Channel. Protestors burn tyres near Calais Photo: GETTY By sea It is worth underlining that ferries are still running from Dover to Calais. Both P&O Ferries (0800 130 0030; poferries.com ) and DFDS (01304 874158; dfdsseaways.co.uk ) are sailing between the ports. Both companies’ websites and Twitter feeds ( @Poferriesupdate ; @dfdsukupdates ) provide regular updates on the travel situation. However, if you wish to avoid Calais entirely, you have a choice of alternative ports. Dunkirk, 30 miles north-east of Calais, is the next best thing – accessible through DFDS. Depending on your destination in France, Normandy may be a plausible point of arrival. • Normandy travel guide • Ferries to France: cheap fares and route details Brittany Ferries (0871 244 1400; brittanyferries.com ) links Portsmouth to Le Havre in just under four hours via catamaran, and in 5½ hours on its conventional ferries. The same operator sails from Portsmouth to Caen in six hours, from Poole to Cherbourg in 4½, and from Portsmouth to Cherbourg via a three-hour fast service. Condor Ferries (0845 609 1024; condorferries.co.uk ) crosses from Portsmouth to Cherbourg in seven hours. DFDS, meanwhile, connects Newhaven and Dieppe in four. • Flight, ferry or train - which is the best way to get to France? Brittany Ferries serves numerous French ports, including Cherbourg Photo: GETTY • Brittany travel guide The beach at St Malo Photo: GETTY Belgium/The Netherlands There is also the option of travelling directly to Belgium or the Netherlands. Try Harwich to the Hook of Holland with Stena Line (0844 770 7070; stenaline.co.uk ), fastest crossing time seven hours. Or Hull to Zeebrugge with P&O Ferries (0800 130 0030; poferries.com ), fastest crossing time: 14 hours 30 mins. Alternatively Hull to Rotterdam with P&O Ferries (0800 130 0030; poferries.com ), fastest crossing time 12 hours. • Amsterdam city guide Travellers from Newcastle can sail direct to Amsterdam Photo: GETTY Spain Finally, there are routes to northern Spain. Plymouth to Santander with Brittany Ferries (0871 244 1400; brittanyferries.com ); Portsmouth to Bilbao, also with Brittany and Portsmouth to Santander, again with Brittany, all have a fastest crossing time of 24 hours. • Calais travel advice: what to do if you have booked a crossing By air While it will mean leaving your car at home and hiring another vehicle once you land, northern France has enough regional airports to make flying a substitute for the ferry – without the hassle of having to go into Paris. Ryanair (0871 246 0000; ryanair.com ) flies from Manchester to Beauvais (50 miles north of Paris) and from Stansted to Deauville. Flybe (0371 700 2000; flybe.com ) flies from Southend to Caen. By rail The Eurotunnel (08443 353 535; eurotunnel.com ) train link to Calais is still functioning. However, while this allows passengers to avoid the ferry but still drive, they should leave extra time for their journey. • Calais travel advice: what to do if you have booked a crossing
